Indian infrastructure companies are facing a cash crunch as a result of the country’s recent economic slowdown, with many in the sector unable to meet their debt obligations, analysts said.
The slowing economy has resulted in a sharp fall in revenue for infrastructural companies, leading to a shortfall in their capex and debts. The situation has become so bad that the companies have had to resort to selling their assets to pay their lenders. In the last 12 months, 25 infrastrucutre companies sold assets worth Rs 6,500 crore to raise crores of rupees. Apart from this, several companies had also defaulted on their interest payments, and the situation is likely to worsen in 3 to 4 years.

The Government of India has initiated various steps to attract private investment in infrastruture projects.
The Indian Government has enacted several legislations to encourage the participation of private players in development and operation of infrastuctures. These legislation include the Indian Electricity Act, 2003, Indian Ports Act 1908, Public-Private Partnership Act (PPP), 3rd Party Access Regulations, etc. Indian Railways has also en- acted the Railway Infrastructure Development Corporation (RIDC) Act for the purpose of providing infrastrutural facilities to the railways.

Indian infrastructure is a mixed bag. A large number of projects are stuck due to issues like land acquisition, environmental clearances and delays in getting approvals from different agencies. Private equities are investors who buy into companies with the aim of making a profit. They do this by invest ing in companies that are undervalued or have the potential to grow. Indian infrastructure development firm, Larsen & Toubro (L&T), has won a $400m (£242m) contract from the Indian government to build a new terminal at the country’s largest airport, Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport (CSIA) in Mumbai.
The terminal, which is being built to meet the growing demand for air travel in India, will be able to handle 45 million passengers a year. The new facility will increase the airports capacity to 105m passengers per year, making it one of the largest in the world. It will also be the first terminal in South Asia to be built on a public-private partnership (PPP) basis. L& T will design, build, finance, operate and maintain the new Terminal 2 for a period of 30 years.

The Indian government has taken several initiatives to improve the country’s infrastructural development.
Infrastructure is the backbone of any economy and it plays a vital role in the economic development of a country. The Indian economy is one of the fastest growing economies in Asia. Infrastructurally, India is a vast country with a large population. Therefore, there is an immense need to develop infrastruc­ture in India. However, the Indian gov­ernment has been facing many challenges in meeting the infrastru­cture needs of its citizens. This has led to a shortage of funds and lack of investments in this sector. To overcome this problem, Indian govern­ment is taking several measures to increase invest­ments and improve infrastr­ucture. These include public-private partnerships (PPPs), infrastruce­r projects, and private investors. Here are some of these initi

Indian infrastructure is set to get a boost as the government is planning to build a network of highways that will connect the country with the rest of the world.
The government has already started the process of building a highway that connects India with China and has also started work on a road that goes from India to Myanmar. The government also plans to connect India and Bangladesh with a railway line that runs through the middle of India. This will allow the two countries to trade with each other. In addition, the Indian government plans on building more roads that run through India’s southern states. These roads will help the people of these states to travel to other parts of their country.

Indian infrastructure development is one of the fastest growing sectors in the world. India has a huge infrastructural requirement and the country has been facing a shortage of funds to finance its infrastrural projects.
The Indian government has come up with the new scheme of infrastrucutral financing called the Infrastructure Debt Fund (IDF) to meet this requirement. The IDF is a special purpose vehicle (SPV) which invests in infrastruture projects and provides long-term debt finanacing to them. This type of finanacring is also known as project finacning. IDFC is the first Indian institution to have raised funds for infrastrutural finanancing. It has raised Rs 3,00, 0 crore from investors. In the last few years, several other institutions have been set up to raise funds. These include IDBI, SBI and ICICI.

Indian infrastructure investment trusts (InvITs) have been a success story, with assets under management (AUM) doubling in less than two years.
Indian infrastructural investments trust ( InvIT) is a hybrid security, which combines the characteristics of an investing company and a real estate investor. The trust is an asset-holding entity, established by an infrastruc-ture company to raise funds from the market to finance the construction, development, management and operation of infrastru-ctural assets. Investors are offered units in the trust and receive a share of the cash flows generated by the underlying assets in return. An InvIIT is structured as a trust, where a sponsor (the infrastruture company) acts as the settler and the investors as trustees. Indian infrastructure projects: the government's new policy
The Indian government has announced a new infrastructural policy to boost the development of the country.
Indian infrastrucutre projects
Infrastructures are the basis of any country' economy, and India has a great need to modernise its infrastrutural system. In this way, the Indian Ministry of Finance has just announced that the Central Government will invest 20 trillion rupees (300 billion euros) in infrastruture projects.
